“That's right, isn’t it, Dounia?” he laughed.

“No, it’s not,” Dounia replied firmly.

“Bah! You have ideals,” he muttered, almost with hatred.

“It's better for you,” he continued, irritation creeping in. “If you overstep, you may be unhappier.”

He paused, vexed. “I beg your forgiveness, mother.”

“That’s enough, Rodya. Everything you do is very good,” she said, delighted.

“Don’t be too sure,” he twisted his mouth into a smile.

Silence fell. Raskolnikov sensed their fear.

“Yet in their absence, I seemed to love them so much,” he thought.

“Rodya, Marfa Petrovna is dead,” his mother suddenly said.

“What Marfa Petrovna?” he asked, confused. 

“Oh, mercy on us—Marfa Petrovna Svidrigaïlov. I wrote you so much about her.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences a complex mix of emotions regarding his family, feeling both love and estrangement as they navigate a tense conversation about ideals and recent tragic news.
